title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants funds for developing and promoting character education initiatives. The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" emphasizes the importance of character education in schools to improve students' ethical values and virtues, promote a compassionate society, and enhance self-esteem while reducing harmful behaviors. Integrating character education into the curriculum fosters the development of core ethical values and virtues in students. Effective character education in schools increases students' self-esteem and reduces the risk of harmful behaviors. Integrating character education into the curriculum fosters the development of core ethical values and virtues in students. States and local educational agencies are increasingly promoting character education initiatives, requiring access to effective methodologies, professional development opportunities, and networking options. The text discusses the importance of character education in schools and the need for comprehensive information on initiatives at the national level. It highlights the necessity of assessing the effectiveness of educational initiatives and the role of a grant to support organizations providing information on character education policies. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an organization with expertise in character education policies, initiatives, and curricula. The grantee must develop initiatives focusing on core ethical values and student behavior. The grantee must use the funds to develop initiatives focusing on core ethical values, student motivation, behavior, schools as caring communities, putting character lessons into practice, involving families and communities, emphasizing leadership, service, and teamwork, and evaluating the effectiveness of character education. The grantee must use grant funds to evaluate the effectiveness of character education initiatives, disseminate information on quality character education methods, professional development models, assessment techniques, integration into educational content, and provide services related to character education implementation. The grantee must use grant funds to provide a searchable database, checklist, website index, and telephone assistance for character education initiatives. They must also submit an annual report on their progress in implementing these requirements. The grantee must provide a searchable database, checklist, website index, and telephone assistance for character education initiatives. They must submit an annual report detailing progress, information requests received, unmet needs, and grant fund usage. $750,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Grant to conduct character education research. Congress finds that states and local educational agencies have received federal funding for character education initiatives in schools, but there are minimal reporting requirements on their impact. The number of schools implementing these initiatives, their success, and the needs of schools starting such initiatives are unknown. Efforts should be made to assess the extent of character education in schools, its effectiveness, and the use of federal funds for these initiatives. Efforts should be made to determine the extent of character education in schools, its effectiveness, and the use of federal funds for these initiatives. The Secretary is authorized to make a 5-year grant to an organization demonstrating expertise in evaluation, research, and developing character education initiatives in schools. The grant recipient must assess character education initiatives in schools, classify approaches, evaluate effectiveness, and report progress to the Secretary annually. The grantee must evaluate character education initiatives in schools, report progress annually to the Secretary, and provide a detailed account of research results and fund usage. $700,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible organization" is defined as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code that has submitted a grant application to the Secretary. A "local educational agency" is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and a "school" includes elementary schools as defined by the same Act. The term "agency" refers to the definition in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. "School" includes elementary and secondary schools as defined in the same Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
